Award.AwardTitle: An Undergraduate Workshop on "Big Data, Human Health and Statistics"
Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop is a concluding event to an Undergraduate Summer Institute on "Big Data, Human Health and Statistics" held at the Department of Biostatistics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor from June 1-26 and is intended to be an event focusing on the undergraduates. The training of the next generation of quantitative scientists needs to change to meet the demands of the data. We define "Big Data" as datasets of enormous size and complexity (either in number of observations, and/or in the number/nature of predictors/outcomes). Classical theory, computation and intuition often fail for such irregular, sparse data sets of vast size. More training in data management, data storage, visualization, high dimensional statistics, optimization, causal methods, modeling sparse data, machine learning are needed to equip students to tackle these big data challenges. It is expected that the knowledge obtained from these massive heterogeneous data sources will inform prevention, screening, prognosis, and treatment of human diseases and play a major role in biology, medicine, and public health in the coming decade. This workshop lies in the intersection of Big Data, Human Health and Statistics.

In this two-day symposium, the first day will feature talks by distinguished researchers in areas of relevance to Big Data, including mobile health, precision medicine, genomics, data visualization. There will be a poster session by undergraduate attendees and an oral presentation session by the undergraduate participants of the summer institute. The second day will be a professional development workshop for undergraduate attendees. Registration will be open to anyone interested (with a maximum limit of 120 participants). The grant will support participation cost of selected undergraduate attendees, faculty mentors and outside speakers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This workshop on Big Data, human health and statistics was held on  June 25-26 in the Department of Biostatistics, University of Michigan with 118 registered participants and 51 of them undergraduates. The workshop introduced and exposed undergraduate students to the shared interdisciplinary landscape needed to address challenges in big data research by fostering interaction with senior researchers and thought leaders in Statistics, Biostatistics, Computer Science and Electrical Engineering.(b) The workshop will enable undergraduate students to disseminate their research through poster and oral presentation. We will recognize meritorious contributions through poster award.(c) The workshop is expected to inspire, motivate and help undergraduate students to pursue higher learning in quantitative fields through the professional development workshop on June 26, especially emphasizing the role of Statistics in Big Data Research. This will serve as a recruiting tool, especially for US citizens and permanent residents. (d) To disseminate new ideas in this dynamic research area through sharing of lectures and slides by pioneers and thought leaders. Four students attending the workshop is starting grdauate school in Biostatistics this Fall at Michigan and 12 others are starting graduate school in quantitative disciplines nationwide.

 

In summary, the workshop created a unique undergraduate research event. It had an impact on the recruitment of future graduate students. The program allowed undergraduate students to interact with a diverse group of stellar faculty and appreciate the big data challenges. It speaks to a very pressing need in higher education to prepare the next generation of students for encountering and appreciating how to attack and solve real-life problems.
